text: please anthony just
do the review hi everyone titanic
here the internet's busiest music nerd
and it's time for a review of this new
alt j album the dream this is a brand
new lp from the uk's alt-j which believe
it or not it's been about 10 years since
i originally covered the band
on their breakout debut in awesome wave
in 2012. time does fly and it's a bit
weird thinking about the band's
output over the years as it's a little
difficult to define much like alt j
sound in general for some reason the
more records alt j comes out with i feel
less familiar with them which i
attribute mostly to the unique way
they've avoided being pigeonholed
stylistically over the years sure on any
given record from them you'll catch
notes of
art pop and folk and singer songwriter
music some electronics as well here and
there and rock but none of their records
head so boldly in any one of these
directions they could be categorized
definitively so while i haven't loved
all of alt j's output thus far they keep
me guessing and there's something to be
said for that like the way they pulled
back on the incredibly subtle and
cerebral this is all yours in 2014. then
there was the wild and messy relaxer in
2017 which
he has my least favorite record from
them so far a lot of little obnoxious
pockets on this one but listening back
to it this record definitely was a risk
the band putting out something this
grading certainly lives up to the
lyrical motto on my least favorite track
from this lp hit me like that snare uh
[ __ ] you i'll do what i want to do shout
out to rage against the machine now
creatively i think the madness continues
in many respects onto the dream but the
band somehow makes a smoother ride of it
this time around and dishes out more
memorable moments in the process too
bane for example is one of the most
dramatic openers i've heard this year
with its spacious folky and kind of
progressive layers of guitar and vocals
and the first leg eventually breaking
into these showy and theatrical coral
sections that transition us into these
drony and enchanting sections of keys
and fat drum beats it's a pleasant sound
i'll say that but then on the lyrical
side
joe newman seems to tell a story
metaphorically or literally about a
young kid who is having a bit of a
fixation on or an addiction to cola soda
sugary drinks newman describing the
cravings and the
sizzle of the bubbles on his tongue as
if it's a fix that haunts him to this
day sure the track is pretty subtle but
i think it's a strong opener for the lp
overall from here we get two of the
teasers from the album that i wasn't
crazy about at first but they have grown
on me there's you and me whose verse
melodies i still find to be pretty
tedious but then there's the chilly
atmosphere and the haunting group
refrains on the chorus it's just you and
me now which have really dug themselves
into my brain plus the rush of strings
and building grooves in the second half
is legitimately stunning too though i
will say the moody and groovy soundtrack
happening here does seem to be a bit of
a disconnect from the story being told
in the lyrics of a a very lavish summer
holiday but simultaneously i guess the
track does reinforce some of the
record's larger themes of
vice and indulgence meanwhile the song
hard drive gold addresses a totally
different deadly sin greed this track is
literally about making fast money in the
age of krypto the thumping bass and drum
grooves and silly little verse lyrics
are
yes preposterous but the band's truly
tongue-in-cheek attitude is revealed by
the time joe newman sings my teacher
took me to one side and told me i was
scum i left and then googled neo-liberal
don't be afraid to make to make money
boy don't be afraid to make to make
money boy
honestly
i love it it may be the funniest song
alt j has ever written if you look at it
simply as a portrayal of this current
new absurd economic reality that we're
facing then happier when you're gone is
a deep cut that might just be one of my
favorite alt-j songs so far it's a
relaxed string laced multi-phased ballad
that has more haunting group choruses
kind of catching notes of m ward on the
guitars and the mix and the lead vocals
too i don't know why it's taken this
long for the similarities between wards
and joan newman's voice to hit me but
yeah they're they're right here
lyrically on this cut we get more images
of drugs and negative influences benzo
timeline cuts smiles into straight lines
instrumentally there's a pretty powerful
finish on this track too the actor by
contrast i thought was a pretty bland
and slowly paced piece of synth pop but
there is a grandiosity to its layering
that i like plus i think lyrically the
band is really locked into a lot of
these themes of addiction and
falling apart this track being about an
actor who has a bit of a coke habit and
is trying to grow their career while
keeping it together get better is a
cerebral and intimate acoustic ballad
that reflects on sickness during our
pandemic times with nods to sending
cards and frontline workers and finding
ways to process and deal with this
hopefully temporary distance i still
pretend you're only out of sight in
another room a younger me a younger you
meeting at the serpentine with also
reference to uh this person's yellow
jeans and how their look defined his
which i think is a bit of a
a weird thing to say honestly i mean i
know i'm having a bit of a giggle at a
very serious track here but when a song
is being written for somebody or about
somebody i tend to think of like how
that person might take
some of the direct lines being said in
the song if if they were uttered you
know right to their face this look
defined my 2009 uh
thanks but still the sentimental vibes
on this track come through and the song
generally feels very heartfelt the
appeal of the song chicago though very
much escapes me the washed out folk
intro doesn't leave a strong impression
fails to draw me in and whatever tune or
song is unfolding past this doesn't
really stand a chance against the
thumping tech house beats that build
past this point newman's vocals and
anything else that he's trying to get
across is just really covered i thought
the unlikely and subtle fusions of art
pop and opera and head nodding beat
loops on the following philadelphia were
a lot better but once again newman's
vocals the narrative and the song in
general feel a little drowned out by the
pomp of the rhythm section and the
strings here the final leg of the lp
offers up a few more surprising moments
there's the barbershop quartet intro on
walk a mile which eventually just moves
into this
very slow spacious and patient blues
rock cut this is the longest song on the
record by a mile but it just doesn't
offer up enough progression across its
length and gets stale before it's even
close to over losing my mind
unfortunately doesn't leave that much
stronger of an impression i wish the
roaring guitar drones that color the
atmosphere in the second half weren't so
gray and dull but the idea of losing
your mind at this point on the record
given all the narratives so far is an
interesting narrative shift and i love
the way newman is able to tie this
feeling to things like
memory a bygone past and the people who
have left with it the instrumental
aesthetics on this lp are just so
dreamy and blissful but as i find again
and again on each of these tracks
there's always a dark undertone lurking
in newman's words but the song powders
kind of ends things on a positive note
with a short snapshot of what looks like
a young love it's pleasant to the ear
but eventually moves into a
skit that sounds like it was ripped
straight out of a bad perfume commercial
in terms of like the dialogue and the
voice acting yeah it's not very good and
i think it ruins the final moments of
the lp honestly like it hits in this
very sour and unexpected way as if i'm
being maced with some fragrance from
calvin klein that i don't want to smell
as i am running my way through a
department store just so i can get to
like the main corridor in the [ __ ]
mall
i don't want this leave me alone so yeah
i think this record starts with a bit of
a bang and then ends in a whisper uh
certainly some of all jay's most
interesting and
bold and out there ideas and experiments
and song concepts so far i love the way
a lot of the themes lyrically across
this lp tie together there are some very
pretty and creative notes of
instrumentation and production across
this thing too but with that being said
for every bop there is on this project i
think there's an equal amount of flops
and i'm not really enjoying this one too
much more
than i did relax or feeling a strong
five to a light six here tran position
